questions.text: A 32-year-old woman sustained an elbow dislocation, and management consisted of an early range of motion. Examination at the 3-month follow-up appointment reveals that she has regained elbow motion but has a weak pinch. A clinical photograph is shown in the Image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anterior interosseous nerve palsy The photograph shows the characteristic attitude of the hand when an anterior interosseous nerve palsy is present. The photograph shows the characteristic attitude of the hand when an anterior interosseous nerve palsy is present. The patient is unable to flex the interphalangeal joint to the joint of the thumb. Anterior interosseous nerve palsies are often misdiagnosed as tendon ruptures.

Highyeild:

Splint used for Brachial plexus injury: Aeroplane splint Brachial plexus is formed by confluence ventral of nerve roots from C5 to T1. Modes of injury either a stab wound or severe traction caused by a fall on the side of neck or the shoulder. Traction injuries are generally classified as supraclavicular, infraclavicular and combined. Supraclavicular lesions typically occurs in motor cycle accident as the cyclist collides with the ground and his neck and shoulder are wrenched apart (may be associated with subclavian artery injury). Infraclavicular lesions are usually associated with fractures or dislocations of the shoulder. & axillary artery injury HYP Splint used for brachial injury is aeroplane splint.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Anterior interosseous nerve palsies are often misdiagnosed as FPL tendon ruptures Option: B. The photograph shows the characteristic attitude of the hand when an anterior interosseous nerve palsy is present, not Median nerve palsy. Option: C. The photograph shows the characteristic attitude of the hand when an anterior interosseous nerve palsy is present, not Ulnar nerve palsy

questions.text: All are the correct match for entrapment neuropathies except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inguinal lig.: - femoral nerve Inguinal ligament is a site for the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh injuries. Common sites for nerve entrapment Carpal tunnel - median nerve Cubital tunnel - ulnar Nerve Less common sites Tarsal tunnel – posterior tibial nerve Inguinal ligament - the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh Suprascapular notch - suprascapular nerve The neck of the fibula - common peroneal nerve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Carpal Tunnel syndrome is Median Nerve entrapment syndrome Option: B. Arcade of Frohse is a common site for PIN entrapment injuries Option: D. Neck of the fibula is a site for common peroneal nerve injury

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extensor carpi radialis longus Extensor carpi radialis longus is supplied by the radial nerve and not the posterior interosseous nerve Extensor carpi radialis longus is supplied by the radial nerve and not the posterior interosseous nerve

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Extensor indicis proprius is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve. Option: B. Extensor carpi ulnaris is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve. Option: C. Extensor digitorum minimi is innervated by the posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains a comminuted distal radius fracture. A closed reduction is performed, and he is placed in a splint. Before leaving the emergency room, he complains of severe pain and paraesthesia in the ipsilateral hand and digits that are uncontrolled by pain medication. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately remove the splint and admit him for observation overnight

options.label: B
options.text: Loosen the splint and ask him to return to the clinic in 2 days for a repeat clinical examination

options.label: C
options.text: Keep the splint in place and discharge him to home with instructions to elevate and ice his upper extremity

options.label: D
options.text: Take him to the operating room for an emergent carpal tunnel release

questions.correct_answer: D. Take him to the operating room for an emergent carpal tunnel release
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Take him to the operating room for an emergent carpal tunnel release In this case scenario following closed reduction the patient complaints of pain and Paraesthesia which indicates median nerve entrapment in the fractured fragments following fracture reduction The next line of management here is to release the nerve from compression as early as possible to prevent permanent damage. MEDIAN nerve injuries are common in distal radius fractures with displacement . In this case scenario following closed reduction the patient complained of pain and Paraesthesia which indicates median nerve entrapment in the fractured fragments following fracture reduction. The next line of management here is to release the nerve from compression as early as possible to prevent permanent damage.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. In this case, the scenario follows the closed reduction the patient complained of pain and Paraesthesia which indicates median nerve entrapment in the fractured fragments following fracture reduction. Observation and splint removal alone will not help reduce compression. Option: B. In this case scenario following closed reduction the patient complained of pain and Paraesthesia which indicates median nerve entrapment in the fractured fragments following fracture reduction. Loosening the splint alone will not help reduce compression. Option: C. In this case, the scenario follows the closed reduction of the patient complaints of pain and Paraesthesia which indicates median nerve entrapment in the fractured fragments following fracture reduction

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complaining of tingling and numbness over the thumb, index finger and middle finger. Also, she felt clumsiness in carrying out fine movements of household work. Tingling is more prominent at night. While asking about history clinician gets to know a past history of Colle's fracture. What is your probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carpal tunnel syndrome It is characterized by compression of the median nerve under the flexor retinaculum at the wrist in the carpal tunnel. It can be idiopathic (most common), post-traumatic, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, myxoedema, and acromegaly. The patient is generally a middle-aged woman with a presentation given in question. A nerve conduction study is an investigation to know the severity of nerve compression. Release of the flexor retinaculum by dividing it is the treatment modality.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Tarsal tunnel syndrome It is a compression, or squeezing, of the posterior tibial nerve that produces symptoms anywhere along the path of the nerve running from the inside of the ankle into the foot. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is similar to carpal tunnel syndrome, which occurs in the wrist. Option: C. Cubital tunnel syndrome It is a compression of the ulnar nerve at the elbow while it passes behind the medial side of the distal humerus. Option: D. Guyon canal syndrome It is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy that involves injury to the distal portion of the ulnar nerve as it travels through a narrow anatomic corridor at the wrist which is called Guyon’s canal.

questions.text: A Diabetic patient complained of Pain, tingling, and numbness around the thumb, index and middle finger, More during the night. Possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carpal Tunnel syndrome A Diabetic patient's complaint of Pain, tingling, and numbness around the thumb, index and middle finger, more during the night is suggestive of Carpal tunnel syndrome.

Highyeild:

Clinical features of Median nerve compression Pain and Paraesthesia occur in the distribution of the median nerve in the hand. Night after night the patient is woken with burning pain, tingling and numbness . Hanging the arm over the side of the bed, or shaking the arm, may relieve the symptoms. Sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve (Tinel’s sign) or By holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds ( Phalen’s test ). In late cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction and sensory dulling in the median nerve territory

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. No features of ulnar nerve injury Option: C. A Diabetic patient's complaint of Pain, tingling, and numbness around the thumb, index and middle finger, more during the night is suggestive of Carpal tunnel syndrome. No features of ulnar nerve injury Option: D. No features of radial nerve compression

questions.text: All are features of anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) syndrome except?

options.label: A
options.text: There is sensory loss on the medial 2 fingers

options.label: B
options.text: Inability to perform OK-sign (approximate thumb and tip of index finger)

options.label: C
options.text: AIN is entrapped under pronator teres, flexor digitorum profundus, flexor carpi radialis

questions.correct_answer: A. There is sensory loss on the medial 2 fingers
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is sensory loss on the medial 2 fingers In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, there is motor weakness without sensory symptoms. Anterior interosseus syndrome is an isolated palsy of flexor pollicis longus , the index and long fingers of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus muscles of the forearm. It manifests as pain in the forearm accompanied commonly by the weakness of the index and thumb finger pincer movement

Highyeild:

Anterior Interosseous Nerve Syndrome The anterior interosseous nerve can be selectively compressed at the same sites as the proximal median nerve. Common causes Spontaneous (and usually temporary) Physiological failure (Parsonage–Turner syndrome) There is motor weakness without sensory symptoms. The patient is unable to make the ‘OK sign ’ – pinching with the thumb and index finger joints flexed, like a ring – because of the weakness of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus. Isolated loss of flexor pollicis longus can occur. The condition usually settles spontaneously within a few months. If it does not, surgical exploration and release or tendon transfer may be considered

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. In Anterior interosseous nerve syndrome, the patient is unable to make the ‘OK sign’ – pinching with the thumb and index finger joints flexed, like a ring – because of the weakness of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus. Option: C. In Anterior interosseous syndrome , AIN is entrapped under pronator teres, flexor digitorum profundus, and flexor carpi radialis. Option: D. The condition usually settles spontaneously within a few months , if it does not, surgical exploration and release or tendon transfer may be considered

questions.text: Knuckle bender splint is used in the management of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ulnar nerve palsy Ulnar nerve palsy - Knuckle-bender splint (lumbricals paralysis)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Radial nerve palsy - Cock-up splint (extensors of wrist & MP joints paralysed) Option: C. Median nerve palsy no splints used Option: D. Common Peroneal nerve palsy - Foot drop splint

questions.text: Identify the Type of Splint shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Knuckle-bender splint Splints are used for various nerve injuries Nerve injured Axillary nerve Aeroplane splint (deltoid paralysis) Radial nerve palsy Cock-up splint (extensors of wrist & MP joints paralysed) Ulnar nerve palsy Knuckle-bender splint (lumbricals paralysis) Sciatic N. palsy or common peroneal nerve Foot drop splint

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A,B & D are not the correct options

questions.text: The clinical test shown in the Image is highly sensitive for which of the following syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carpal tunnel syndrome The given test is Phalen’s test done for Carpel Tunnel syndrome. Carpal tunnel syndrome – Phalen’s test and Durkan’s test.

Highyeild:

DURKAN TEST/ Carpal compression test Pressure over the carpal tunnel for 30 seconds produce tingling or shock in the median nerve. Wrist should be in neutral position and forearm supinated. Clinical features of Median nerve compression Pain and Paraesthesia occur in the distribution of the median nerve in the hand. Night after night the patient is woken with burning pain, tingling and numbness. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed, or shaking the arm, may relieve the symptoms. Sensory symptoms can often be reproduced by percussing over the median nerve (Tinel’s sign) or By holding the wrist fully flexed for less than 60 seconds (Phalen’s test). In late cases, there is wasting of the thenar muscles, weakness of thumb abduction and sensory dulling in the median nerve territory

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Dupuytren’s contracture – Hueson’s tabletop test Option: C. Dequervain’s tenosynovitis – Finkelstein's test Option: D. Student’s elbow – also called Olecranon bursitis, no known test

options.label: C
options.text: Entrapment syndrome of the digital nerves of toes

questions.correct_answer: C. Entrapment syndrome of the digital nerves of toes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Entrapment syndrome of the digital nerves of toes . Entrapment syndrome of the digital nerves of toes is called Interdigital nerve compression (Morton’s metatarsalgia)

Highyeild:

Interdigital nerve compression (Morton’s metatarsalgia) Morton’s metatarsalgia is a common problem, with neuralgia affecting a single distal metatarsal interspace. It is essentially an entrapment or compression syndrome affecting one of the digital nerves Usually the third (affecting the third and fourth toe). The patient typically complains of pain on walking, with the sensation of walking on a pebble in the shoe, or of the sock being rucked up under the ball of the foot. The pain is worse in tight footwear and often has to be relieved by removing the footwear and massaging the foot. Activities that load the forefoot (running, jumping, dancing) exacerbate the condition Treatment Simple offloading of the metatarsal heads by using a metatarsal dome insole and wider-fitting shoes may help. If symptoms do not improve with these measures, a steroid injection into the interspace. Surgical intervention

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Hairline fracture – a tiny crack in a bone due to repetitive stress or force. Option: B. Stress fracture caused by overuse and repetitive activity. Option: D. Synovitis of the interphalangeal joint is seen in Rheumatoid arthritis
